subject: English
title: Use non-verbal cues and adjust volume/pace to support meaning

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Uses basic gestures/facial expression; speaks audibly at times with adult prompting.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Usually uses facial expression/gesture that match ideas; adjusts volume OR pace with reminders.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Consistently uses non-verbal cues that reinforce the message; adjusts both volume and pace for clarity.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Chooses non-verbal cues purposefully (e.g., posture, proximity) and varies volume/pace to emphasise ideas.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Integrates non-verbal cues, volume, and pace flexibly for audience and purpose; can explain choices.

detection_hints: References to facial expressions, gestures, posture, proximity during presentations

evidence_examples.example: Student slows pace and makes eye contact when sharing a key point.
NZSL signer adjusts signing speed and facial grammar to show emphasis.

accessibility_notes: Be mindful of cultural differences and neurodivergent preferences when teaching non-verbal communication.

ell_alignment.notes: Make explicit links between non-verbal cues and meaning; model across languages.

next_steps: Model and rehearse paired presentations; add visual prompts for when to slow, pause, or gesture.

success_examples.excerpt: I slowed down to show it was important and pointed to my diagram.

subject: English
title: Demonstrate active listening and respectful turn-taking

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Looks toward speaker and responds with single words or signs when prompted.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Follows simple turn-taking cues; offers short relevant responses; may need reminders to listen.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Maintains topic, asks/answers simple questions, and responds respectfully without prompting.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Builds on others’ ideas and rephrases key points to show understanding.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Guides discussion by inviting others to contribute and summarising shared ideas.

detection_hints: Phrases like 'I agree… because…', 'I heard you say…'
Teacher notes of topic maintenance and respectful language

evidence_examples.example: Turns to each speaker and nods before responding.

accessibility_notes: Provide sentence stems/visual turn-taking cues; ensure audibility/visibility of speakers.

ell_alignment.notes: Model question frames; pre-teach topic vocabulary.

next_steps: Introduce discussion roles (e.g., 'questioner', 'summariser') and sentence starters.

success_examples.excerpt: Can you add on to her idea?

subject: English
title: Ask and answer why/how and if/then questions to explain ideas

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Answers simple who/what/where questions with support.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Asks/answers why or how questions about familiar events; uses basic because/so.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Uses if/then and when/unless/as long as to explain causes and outcomes.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Generates open questions to extend thinking; links multiple causes/effects.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Evaluates alternative causes and predicts outcomes across contexts.

evidence_examples.example: ‘If we add more water, then it will overflow.’

accessibility_notes: Provide visual cue cards for causal connectives; allow extra processing time.

ell_alignment.notes: Map connectives to home-language equivalents where possible.

next_steps: Introduce question mats with closed vs open prompts; rehearse paired 'why/how' interviews.

success_examples.excerpt: ‘We stayed inside because it was raining.’

subject: English
title: Prepare and present short recitations/oral presentations using prompts

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Recites short items with group support; uses visual cues provided by teacher.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Presents a short item with scaffolded notes or visuals.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Presents a short talk with independently prepared prompts; message generally clear.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Organises ideas with clear beginning/middle/end; uses prompts to maintain flow.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Adapts prompts and delivery to audience; answers questions about content.

evidence_examples.example: Student uses two self-made picture cards during a one-minute talk.

accessibility_notes: Offer multiple prompt types (icons, keywords, NZSL glosses).

ell_alignment.notes: Allow bilingual prompts; pre-teach key nouns/verbs.

next_steps: Co-construct success criteria (voice, pace, prompts); provide audience feedback stems.

subject: English
title: Pronounce and map less-common grapheme–phoneme correspondences

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Identifies common sounds for taught single letters in decodables.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Reads common digraphs and some vowel teams in familiar words.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Pronounces correct phonemes for less-common GPCs (e.g., <eigh>→/ā/, <sc>→/s/) in controlled texts.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Generalises less-common GPCs to new words; self-corrects using GPC knowledge.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Explains multiple spellings for a phoneme and chooses correctly in context when writing/reading.

detection_hints: Teacher running records noting accuracy on <eigh>, <sc>, etc.
accessibility_notes: Teach mouth pictures/handshapes; anchor cards for unusual GPCs.

ell_alignment.notes: Contrast with phonemes in known languages; explicit articulation support.

next_steps: Cumulative review of rare GPCs; build word lists and games for <eigh>/<sc>/<tch>/<dge>.

subject: English
title: Decode diphthongs and r-controlled vowels in taught words

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Recognises diphthong patterns in isolation with support.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Reads common diphthongs (e.g., /oi/ in 'coin') in familiar words.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Accurately reads diphthongs and r-controlled vowels (e.g., 'bird', 'farm') in decodable texts.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Applies patterns to unfamiliar words; self-corrects using phoneme–grapheme mapping.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Explains how the <r> changes the vowel sound and identifies exceptions.

next_steps: Review with cumulative word banks; add connected text practice.

success_examples.excerpt: ‘The bird will turn…’ read without prompts.

subject: English
title: Use decodables for practice and rich read-alouds to build language

policy_reference.source_title: English Year 3 Teaching Sequence (Working with texts)

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Listens to daily read-alouds; practises taught GPCs in decodables with support.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Participates in read-aloud talk; reads decodables that match recent phonics teaching.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Explains something learned from a read-aloud and demonstrates accurate decoding in matched decodables.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Transfers vocabulary/structures from read-alouds into own talk/writing; selects decodables to practise new GPCs.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Chooses texts for purpose/enjoyment; articulates how decodable practice supports reading growth.

detection_hints: Teacher plan shows daily read-aloud + decodable rotation

evidence_examples.example: Selects a decodable aligned to this week’s GPCs.

accessibility_notes: Ensure less-constrained read-alouds reflect identities/languages; provide captions/visuals.

ell_alignment.notes: Use bilingual read-alouds; pre-teach key vocabulary.

next_steps: Track decodable–phonics alignment; build read-aloud text set by theme.

subject: English
title: Make simple inferences and use text features to support meaning

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Identifies who/what/where with illustrations or teacher prompts.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Uses pictures and headings to answer simple questions.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Makes simple inferences by linking ideas and prior knowledge; uses subheadings/glossaries to locate information.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Explains how a feature (diagram, footnote) helps understanding; supports an inference with evidence.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Compares ideas across pages/texts and justifies inferences with multiple clues.

detection_hints: Mentions of 'because the picture shows…', 'the glossary says…'
Student highlights a text box/subheading when answering

evidence_examples.example: Annotates a page to show clues used for an inference.

accessibility_notes: Choose texts with clear visuals and teach explicit navigation of features.

ell_alignment.notes: Pre-teach feature labels; offer bilingual glossaries.

next_steps: Use 'Because–So' frames to justify inferences; practice scanning with headings.

success_examples.excerpt: ‘Maybe he’s late because the map shows a long path.’

subject: English
title: Compose short sentences using taught GPCs and text models

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Produces labels or single-word attempts using taught letter-sounds.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Writes simple sentences with mostly correct GPCs; punctuation may be inconsistent.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Writes short linked sentences modelled on class texts; uses capital letters and full stops reliably.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Varies sentence starters and includes detail from mentor texts; edits for clarity.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Explains choices (word, structure) based on the model text and audience.

detection_hints: Evidence of GPC application in spelling

evidence_examples.example: Two connected sentences about a topic using current phonics patterns.

accessibility_notes: Offer scribing/keyboard options; provide sentence frames drawn from read-alouds.

ell_alignment.notes: Use bilingual word banks; permit translanguaging in planning.

next_steps: Add conjunctions (and/but/because); mini-lessons on capitals/full stops from shared writing.

success_examples.excerpt: ‘We went to the farm and I fed a red hen.’

subject: English
title: Organise ideas in a simple paragraph using headings or sequence language

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Writes/arranges ideas as a list or picture labels.
progress_descriptors.Developing: Uses sequence words (first/then/finally) to order ideas with support.
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Groups related sentences as a simple paragraph; may use a heading or subheading.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Uses a clear topic sentence and supporting detail; refers to diagrams/maps as needed.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Adds concluding idea or reflection and links to another paragraph or source.

evidence_examples.example: Short paragraph with a heading and two supporting details linked to a diagram.

accessibility_notes: Graphic organisers; sentence stems; allow multimodal evidence (labelled diagrams).

ell_alignment.notes: Provide bilingual headings and labelled visuals.

next_steps: Teach topic/support/conclusion frames; integrate vocabulary from read-alouds.

success_examples.excerpt: Heading: ‘Kauri Forest’. Topic sentence + two facts; labelled map.

subject: English
title: Use reflective language to describe steps, strategies, and next moves

policy_reference.source_title: English Year 2 Teaching Sequence – Reflective/strategic communication

progress_descriptors.Emerging: Names a step taken when prompted (‘first I…’).
progress_descriptors.Developing: Uses simple frames to describe process or feelings (‘I found it tricky when…’).
progress_descriptors.Consolidating: Explains steps, strategies, and feelings using sequencing and evaluative phrases.
progress_descriptors.Proficient: Identifies strengths and next steps; links choices to outcomes.
progress_descriptors.Exceeding: Poses probing questions about learning and plans a specific next move.

detection_hints: Use of frames: ‘first… then…’, ‘I did well at…’, ‘I need to work on…’

evidence_examples.example: ‘First I planned, then I wrote. Next time I will add a diagram.’

accessibility_notes: Provide visual sentence stems; accept multimodal reflections (voice/NZSL/video).

ell_alignment.notes: Pre-teach evaluative vocabulary; allow bilingual reflection.

next_steps: Introduce ‘Because–So’ frames to justify strategies and results.

success_examples.excerpt: ‘I used a strategy like doubles. I need to work on tidy tens.’
